April 27, 1907

712483f-a.text:
30, 28, 26, 24 East 38th Street, south side, adjoining the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue.

About 1910.

721290f-a.text:
Madison Avenue (right), at the S. E. corner of East 38th (left) Street, showing the Fifth Church of Christ Scientist. This structure was Tormerly occupied by the congregation of South Reformed Dutch Church, whopurchased it in 1890 from the 5ion Episcopal Church. A spire was mounted atop the tower at that time, tho not evldent at this date. To the left is a view eastward on the south side of 38th Street, to Park Avenue. Two private buildings separate the Church from the Bonar Law mansion at 37th Street. This later became the National Democratic Headquarters, while the Church
site was improved with the Midston Club.
About 1915
Underhill, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

721284f-b.text:
(1)
Madison Avenue, east side, north from 38th Street, showing close-up of small buildings which are to be demolished that August. Note above them and in line, tops of Chanin and
Chrysler buildings.
February 23, 1931.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
Madison Avenue, east side, north from 38th Street. Buildings are being razed in 38th to 39th Street block, where open air parking space will be established the following month.
August 26, 1931.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

721288f-a.text:
Madison Ave., at the N.E. corner of East 38th Street. 'o-day (1B37) a parking lot occupies this block front from 38th to 39th Streets. Note the Chanin and Chrysler Buildings across the background.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

721293f-b.text:
(1)
252, 244, 240 Madison Avenue, west side at 38th Street, from 39th Street across the open-air parking place on the east side. The mooring mast of the Empire State Building is seen over the top of the Heckscher Building at the S.W. corner of 38th Street.
July 10, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, another view. The little girl in the foreground has
turned towards the camera.
July 10, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same scene on a week-day, the preceding autumn, shortly
after this parking space was first established.
October 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

721296f-c.text:
Madison Ave., west side, from East 38th (left) to 39th (right) Streets, showing an entire block front that is owned by the Baker family. The photographer is viewing westward across a demolition on the east aide of the Ave. and upon which an open-air car parking enterprise will continue in business until the present (1938). This set consists of
three views.
The former residence of William Goadby Loew, at the S.W. corner of Madison Ave. and East 39th Street (shown 3n the right) has been purchased by the Henry Visiting Nurse Service. They will move their executive offices from No. 99 Park Ave., a structure that they have occupied since 1921 and which has been purchased by the City as a portion of the site for the new Appellate Division Court House. For a fuller account see
the New York Times of March 25, 1938.
August 25, 1931.
Views 2 & 3:-0ctober 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
The Baker Estate interests are endeavoring to re-zone the balance of this Madison Avenue frontage from residential use to commercial and
are offering same for sale at this date April 11, 1938.

712482f-a.text:
East 38th Street, at, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Madis on Ave. Shown directly at the corner is the Midston Club (No. 22). Shown on the extreme right, is the west side of Madison Ave., south from 38th to 37t
Streets.
About 1936.

721285f-b.text:
Madison Avenue, west side, north from East 38th Street, showing the cleared 38th-39th Street frontage, and it's solitary Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service administration building suurrounded by various office structures. Among the latter is the towering No. 10 E. 40th St. Bldg. Note the cleared easterly portion of the Avenue and across which two of these views are photographed.
May 27, 1939
P. L. Sperr

712481f.text:
38th Street, south side, west from Madison Avenue, showing the former residence of the late Theodore A. Havemeyer on the S.W. corner of Madison Avenue. This will be demolished late in 1915.
May 2, 1907.
Brown Brothers.

721282f-c.text:
(1)
Madison Svenue, west side, north from W. 38th Street. (intersection in foreground). In the left foreground, betwween 38th and 39th Street are low structures,ithe property of the Baker family) that will with the exclusion of No. 262 Madison 'Svenue (S.d. corner of 39th St.) be demolished in the Spring of 1939. his row consists of 4 structures which are respectively, the Professional Building, the George F. Baker home, his sons house,and his daughters (Mrs. Wm. Goadby Loew)home. The last is the brownstone and is referred to ahove as remaining. The Henry Street Nurses have rurchased same and will renovate it to conform with
their purposes (Fall 1939).
October 2, 1931
P.L.Sperr
(2)
View No. 2 is photographed across the lot on the east side of the Avenue and is directed towards 39th Street. The 3 office buildings shown are
on the 39th - 4Oth Street frontage.
October 2, 1931
P.L.Sperr
(3)
'iew No. 3 is taken during the afore mentioned demolition and shows the elder ~alers home and his sons. At the right is the already rehabilitated
Henry Street Nurses headcuarters.
In the left background of all three views anpears a portion of the towering building. No. 10 Nast 49th Street.
March 26, 1939
.W. Hi11
